title: Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2014
description: In 2014, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($341,468,050), AidData has taken the average price ($93.17) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2014 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
staff_comments: 1. In 2012, a North Korean source disclosed that every year ‘the Ministry of Commerce of China and the North Korean government will discuss the catalogue of aid products, quantity, period, etc., but it is basically 100,000 tons of grain, 500,000 tons of oil, and materials needed by North Korea worth 20 million US dollars.’  This annual oil donation arrangement between the Chinese Government and the North Korean Government dates back to the 1970s. On October 17, 1970, the Chinese Government and the Government of North Korea signed an Agreement on Mutual Supply of Critical Materials 1971-1976. Under the terms of this agreement, the Chinese Government agreed to provide the North Korean Government with 500,000 tons of crude oil per year.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese Government donates 500,000 tons of crude oil in 2014

# Description
In 2014, the Chinese Government donated approximately 500,000 tons of crude oil to the North Korean Government. 500,000 tons of oil is equivalent to 3,665,000 barrels of oil. Therefore, to estimate the monetary value of this donation ($341,468,050), AidData has taken the average price ($93.17) of a barrel of West Texas Intermediate (NYMEX) crude oil in 2014 and multiplied it by 3,665,000 barrels of oil. This crude oil donation project was supported via recurring grants from China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) between 2000 and 2017.  Since 1991, China has been North Korea's largest crude oil provider, making up 80% of its supply. Crude oil is provided to North Korea through a pipeline (known as the Dandong-Sinuiju Pipeline or Friendship Oil Pipeline) from the Daqing Oil Field, 800 kilometers north of the China-North Korea border. The pipeline, which was completed in December 1975, runs for more than 30 km from storage facilities in the Chinese border city of Dandong to an oil depot in Sinuiju in North Korea. It supplies approximately 520,000 tons (3.64 million barrels) of heavy crude oil each year, according to its operator, China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC). Once across the border, the crude oil is processed at North Korea's sole working refinery, the Ponghwa Chemical Factory, a facility built with Chinese assistance during the 1970s. The refinery turns the oil into refined products for North Korea's government, military, transport, agricultural and fishing sectors.
justification: Project involves donation of crude oil, a fossil fuel, supporting North Korea's oil-dependent sectors
evidence: 500,000 tons of crude oil donation, pipeline infrastructure, processing at oil refinery

title: CDB provides $225 million loan for Kinsenda Copper Development Project
description: On May 29, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $225 million loan to Kinsenda Copper Company SARL — a project company and subsidiary of Jinchuan Group International Resources Co. Ltd — for the Kinsenda Copper Development Project. The maturity of the loan is 12 years. However, the other borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.   The Kinsenda Copper Development Project is a brownfield project situated in the Katanga Province of the DRC and it ranks as one of the world’s highest grade copper deposits. The project has good access to infrastructure, with a sealed single-lane road connecting the mine to the regional highway 20 km to the west of the site. It involves revitalized an existing mine (that was first development in 1980) into an 24,000 tonnes per annum copper concentrate mine.   Construction began in 2013 and the project was originally expected to reach completion in 2015. However, due to unfavorable ground conditions and flooding of underground works, the project was rescheduled to be commissioned in 2017. The capital expenditure on the Kinsenda Project for the year ended December 31, 2014 was $192.7 million. These funds were primarily spent on the construction and development of the plant and the mine.  The Kinsenda Copper mine completed 107% of the annual plan for net profit after tax, its best operational performance since it was put into operation in 2018.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 金森達銅礦位.
combined_text:
# Sector

# Title

# Description
On May 29, 2014, China Development Bank (CDB) provided a $225 million loan to Kinsenda Copper Company SARL — a project company and subsidiary of Jinchuan Group International Resources Co. Ltd — for the Kinsenda Copper Development Project. The maturity of the loan is 12 years. However, the other borrowing terms of the loan are unknown.   The Kinsenda Copper Development Project is a brownfield project situated in the Katanga Province of the DRC and it ranks as one of the world’s highest grade copper deposits. The project has good access to infrastructure, with a sealed single-lane road connecting the mine to the regional highway 20 km to the west of the site. It involves revitalized an existing mine (that was first development in 1980) into an 24,000 tonnes per annum copper concentrate mine.   Construction began in 2013 and the project was originally expected to reach completion in 2015. However, due to unfavorable ground conditions and flooding of underground works, the project was rescheduled to be commissioned in 2017. The capital expenditure on the Kinsenda Project for the year ended December 31, 2014 was $192.7 million. These funds were primarily spent on the construction and development of the plant and the mine.  The Kinsenda Copper mine completed 107% of the annual plan for net profit after tax, its best operational performance since it was put into operation in 2018.
justification: Copper mining project targeting a critical mineral for energy transition technologies
evidence: Development of a copper mine producing 24,000 tonnes per annum of copper concentrate, copper explicitly mentioned as target mineral

title: Chinese Government donates Ebola prevention and treatment equipment worth RMB 5 million
description: On September 26, 2014, Wang Yingwu, Chinese Ambassador to DRC, and Dismas Swana Emina Monzia Magbengu, the Vice Minister of International and Regional Cooperation of the DRC, signed letters of exchange for the donation of prevention and treatment equipment to combat Ebola. Earlier on September 23, 2014, the Chinese Embassy announced that prevention and treatment equipment valued at 5 million RMB would be donated to DRC, and 3 medical experts would also be allocated to the DRC. The equipment reportedly included 17,000 protective suits, goggles, gloves, and body bags. The donated materials arrived in Kinshasa, and on October 29, 2014, the handover ceremony of the donated materials took place at Kinshasa's airport. This project is completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates Ebola prevention and treatment equipment worth RMB 5 million

# Description
On September 26, 2014, Wang Yingwu, Chinese Ambassador to DRC, and Dismas Swana Emina Monzia Magbengu, the Vice Minister of International and Regional Cooperation of the DRC, signed letters of exchange for the donation of prevention and treatment equipment to combat Ebola. Earlier on September 23, 2014, the Chinese Embassy announced that prevention and treatment equipment valued at 5 million RMB would be donated to DRC, and 3 medical experts would also be allocated to the DRC. The equipment reportedly included 17,000 protective suits, goggles, gloves, and body bags. The donated materials arrived in Kinshasa, and on October 29, 2014, the handover ceremony of the donated materials took place at Kinshasa's airport. This project is completed.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare and disease prevention without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of Ebola prevention and treatment equipment, medical experts deployment, healthcare focus

title: Chinese Government dispatches 16th medical team to Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital in N'djili
description: In 2014, the Chinese Government dispatched the 16th medical team to the Democratic Republic of Congo. The 16th medical team consisted of 17 members who were stationed at the Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital, which is located in N'djili, Kinshasa. The team completed its term of service between May 2014 and June 3, 2016. The Chinese Government also provided an RMB 48 million grant for the construction of the Sino-Congolese Friendship Hospital (recorded in project #438).  The Chinese Government has been sending medical teams to the Democratic Republic of Congo since 1973. However, due to internal turmoil, the Chinese Government stopped sending medical teams from 1997 to 2008. Hubei Province has been responsible for sending the medical teams.
combined_text:

title: Chinese Government provides grant for Ngiri-Ngiri Primary School Improvement Project (Linked to Project ID#19114)
description: On October 25, 2014, the Ngiri-Ngiri primary school public welfare renovation project was completed. This project involved the rebuilding of the disused primary school in the Ngiri-Ngiri municipality, and was jointly funded by the Chinese Embassy in the DR Congo, Chinese Enterprise Association, and Chinese expatriates. Besides renovating the school, these organizations also donated school supplies to the school. The value of the renovations and the donations are unknown. This school was constructed with Chinese assistance in 2009, which is recorded in the linked project #19114. This project is completed.

title: Chinese Government provides $5,958,061.47 grant for People's Palace Rehabilitation Works Project
description: In 2014, the Chinese Government provided a $5,958,061.47 grant to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for the People's Palace Rehabilitation Works Project. The purpose of this project was to rehabilitate the People's Palace (Chinese name: 人民宫) in Kinshasa. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), $5,761,682.24 was disbursed in support of this project.  The French project title is Travaux de réhabilitation du Palais du Peuple.

title: Chinese Government provides $9,411,529 grant for Martyrs Stadium Rehabilitation Works Project (Linked to projects #31415, #58960, and #58962)
description: In 2014, the Chinese Government provided a $9,411,529.83 grant to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo for the Martyrs Stadium Rehabilitation Works Project. The purpose of this project was to facilitate the rehabilitation of Martyrs Stadium (Chinese name: 金沙萨烈士体育场) in Kinshasa. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), $9,099,578.80 was disbursed in support of this project as of July 2019. Several other Chinese Government grants were issued in support of Martyrs Stadium, including those recorded in projects #31415, #58960, and #58962. It is also likely that project #58960 provided supplemental funding for this project.  The French project title is Travaux de la réhabilitation du Stade des Martyres.

title: Chinese Government makes 9th annual anti-malarial drug donation worth $330,354.64 (Linked to Project ID#59101)
description: As part of a FOCAC commitment, the Chinese Government donated malaria medications to the DRC every year from 2006 to 2016 (see Project ID#59101). In 2014, the Chinese Government granted the 9th batch of malaria medications to the Government Democratic Republic of Congo. According to the Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP), the project is funded by the Chinese Embassy and the monetary value of this grant commitment was $330,354.64.   The yearly donations are as follows:  2006: #19719  2007: #59102  2008: #59104  2009: #59105  2010: #59106  2011: #59108  2012: #59109  2013: #59111  2014: #53518  2015: #52957  2016: #58975
staff_comments: The French project title is Médicaments anti-palutique.

title: Chinese government grants $371,648 for training of 40 Congolese civil servants
description: In 2014, the Chinese Government committed $371,648.97 of grant funding for the training of 40 civil servants from various Democratic Republic of Congo ministries. It is unclear whether the training took place in China or DRC. As of July 2019, $362,219.68 had been disbursed for this project.  The French project title is Formation des 40 fonctionnaires des Ministères de la RDC en 2014.

title: Chinese Embassy provides $1,140,985 for Phase 5 of Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Technical Cooperation Project in N'sele
description: On August 4, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to DRC, Fan Zhenshui, went to N'sele to attend the inauguration ceremony of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Centre (also referred to as Upland Crops) (French project name: Projet de Vulgarisation Des Cultures Pluviales à Kinshasa/N'sele). The construction of basic infrastructure at the demonstration centre was completed in November 2007. Then, in 2008, the project transitioned to a technical cooperation arrangement.   The first phase of the technical cooperation was carried out from August 2009 to August 2010 by Shandong International Economic and Technological Cooperation Company. The Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) records a 2014 commitment value of $1,140,985.91 from the Chinese Embassy for Phase V of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project [French project name: Coopération technique du projet de vulgarisation des cultures pluviales à N'sele (5ème phase)]. As of July 2019, the final amount disbursed for this phase was $640,368.85.   There are five known technical cooperation phases for the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project: Phase I: $3,420,254 (recorded in project #58963)  Phase II: $1,485,974 (recorded in project #58964)  Phase III: $673,453 (recorded in project #58965)  Phase IV: $353,039 (recorded in project #58966)  Phase V: $1,140,985 (recorded in project #58967)  There is additional financing for the 2nd and 3rd technical cooperation phase: Phases II & III: $8,535,963 (recorded in project #58968); and a project to bring water and electricity and level the land of the site: $364,701 (recorded in project #58969).
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Embassy provides $1,140,985 for Phase 5 of Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Technical Cooperation Project in N'sele

# Description
On August 4, 2006, the Chinese ambassador to DRC, Fan Zhenshui, went to N'sele to attend the inauguration ceremony of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Centre (also referred to as Upland Crops) (French project name: Projet de Vulgarisation Des Cultures Pluviales à Kinshasa/N'sele). The construction of basic infrastructure at the demonstration centre was completed in November 2007. Then, in 2008, the project transitioned to a technical cooperation arrangement.   The first phase of the technical cooperation was carried out from August 2009 to August 2010 by Shandong International Economic and Technological Cooperation Company. The Government of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s Aid Management Platform (AMP) records a 2014 commitment value of $1,140,985.91 from the Chinese Embassy for Phase V of the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project [French project name: Coopération technique du projet de vulgarisation des cultures pluviales à N'sele (5ème phase)]. As of July 2019, the final amount disbursed for this phase was $640,368.85.   There are five known technical cooperation phases for the Rain-fed Crop Demonstration Center Project: Phase I: $3,420,254 (recorded in project #58963)  Phase II: $1,485,974 (recorded in project #58964)  Phase III: $673,453 (recorded in project #58965)  Phase IV: $353,039 (recorded in project #58966)  Phase V: $1,140,985 (recorded in project #58967)  There is additional financing for the 2nd and 3rd technical cooperation phase: Phases II & III: $8,535,963 (recorded in project #58968); and a project to bring water and electricity and level the land of the site: $364,701 (recorded in project #58969).
justification: Agricultural demonstration center focused on crop development and technical cooperation, with no clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Rain-fed crop demonstration center, technical cooperation phases, agricultural focus
